channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Trump says he's fighting crime. Illinois Gov. Pritzker sees a power grab before 2026
item.description: Steve Inskeep speaks with Illinois Governor JB Pritzker about President Trump's threats to send National Guard troops to Chicago and the future of the Democratic Party.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Israel launches airstrike targeting Hamas in Qatar, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker criticizes Trump's surge of immigration agents in Chicago, administration released plan to improve children's health.

item.title: Salome Zourabichvili, incumbent president of Georgia, refuses to stand down
item.description: Nearly a year after parliamentary elections, Georgia's incumbent president refuses to stand down. NPR speaks with Salome Zourabichvili, who says Russia rigged voting and that she is the legitimate president.

item.title: Trump signs memo directing FDA to crack down on pharmaceutical ads
item.description: President Trump signed a memo on Tuesday directing the FDA to crack down on direct-to-consumer drug advertisements. But there are limits to what any administration can do.

item.title: What the downward revision in jobs numbers indicates about the U.S. economy
item.description: What does the sharp downward revision in jobs data suggest about the health of the U.S. economy? NPR speaks with David Wessel, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

item.title: President Trump's control of the D.C. police force is set to end at midnight
item.description: On Wednesday, Trump will give up control of D.C.'s police force after his unprecedented intervention in the nation's capital is set to end. There are varying opinions on the impact of this action.

item.title: Fake sober living homes in Arizona leave legacy of mistrust among people in need
item.description: Survivors of fake sober living homes in Arizona that were set up to defraud Medicaid say those homes left a legacy of mistrust, and are making it harder for people who need help to recover.

item.title: Shipwreck hunters find SS James Carruthers at bottom of Lake Huron
item.description: Shipwreck hunters found the SS James Carruthers, a wheat-carrying cargo ship that sank in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. It's belly up in the bed of Lake Huron.

item.title: The band Big Thief discusses their sixth studio album, 'Double Infinity'
item.description: Big Thief has a way of asking the big questions by focusing on the smallest details. NPR's A Martinez speaks with the indie band about "Double Infinity," their sixth studio album.

item.title: Israel launches airstrike targeting Hamas members in Qatar
item.description: An Israeli airstrike in Qatar on Tuesday targeted Hamas leadership in a sharp escalation that brought the war to a country that is a U.S. ally and key mediator in the war in Gaza.
